content: How can I help you today?
I've just been really struggling with sleep lately. There’s so much going on with work, and I can’t seem to shut my brain off at night. It’s been tough to deal with.

That sounds really challenging—having work on your mind and feeling unable to wind down at night can take a toll physically and emotionally. Sleep struggles often make everything else feel even harder. What’s been on your mind about this lately?

Honestly, it's mostly work stress. I'm constantly worried about getting fired and not being able to support my family. It feels like the thoughts just don't stop, and then I end up looking at my phone to distract myself, which probably makes things worse. It's like a vicious cycle.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of weight on your shoulders—worrying about your family, your job, and trying to find ways to cope. It must be exhausting to feel stuck in that cycle, especially when it impacts your sleep. How do you feel about the ways you've been trying to manage this stress so far?

To be honest, I feel like I'm not managing it very well. I know looking at my phone isn't helping, but it feels like the only way to distract myself from all these racing thoughts. I just don’t know what else to do.

It sounds like you’re trying to find relief in the moment, even though part of you recognizes it might not be helping in the long run. Feeling unsure of what else to do can be overwhelming. What do you think might help shift things, even in small ways, if you were to try something different?

I don’t know. I’ve thought about things like shutting my phone off at night or trying to journal my thoughts, but I don’t really think those will work. It feels like the stress and anxiety is just too much, no matter what I try. Maybe I’m too skeptical to believe anything will actually help.

It sounds like there’s a lot of skepticism about whether anything can truly make a difference, especially when the stress and anxiety feel so overwhelming. Even with those doubts, you’ve already thought about ideas like journaling or shutting off your phone, which shows you're open to exploring possibilities, even if you're unsure they'll work. What matters most to you when you think about trying to relieve some of this stress?

I guess what matters most is being able to show up for my partner and kids. I don’t want to feel this drained and disconnected all the time. They deserve more from me, and I want to be able to focus on them instead of being stuck in my head all day.

You care deeply about your partner and kids, and you want to be present and engaged with them—that’s incredibly meaningful. Feeling drained and stuck in your thoughts can make it hard to give them the attention you want to give. What would it mean to you if you were able to find ways to feel a bit more present and connected with them?

I think it would mean a lot. I'd feel like I was actually being the kind of partner and parent I want to be, instead of just going through the motions. It would take away some of the guilt I feel for being so stressed all the time, and maybe I’d feel a little more like myself again.

It sounds like reconnecting with your family and feeling more like yourself is really important to you—it’s something you value deeply. That guilt you’re carrying shows how much you care, even when stress pulls you away. What do you think might help you take small steps toward feeling more present and lighter in your day-to-day life?

I guess maybe I could try turning off my phone at night, just to see if it helps a little. It feels hard to do, though, since it's become such a habit. Maybe I could also try writing some of my thoughts down before bed, but I’m not sure if I’d stick to it. It feels overwhelming to think about changing my routine, even if I want to.

You’re recognizing changes you could try—like turning off your phone or writing down your thoughts—but also acknowledging how overwhelming it feels to shift habits, especially ones that have become routine. Making changes can feel like a big hurdle, even when the desire is there. What could make it feel a little more manageable to take a small step forward with either of those ideas?

Maybe I could start by just setting a time limit on my phone at night instead of turning it off completely. That might feel less intimidating. And with writing, maybe I could just keep a notebook by my bed and write a few quick things down instead of trying to do a lot. Small steps might feel like less pressure.

Small steps like setting a time limit on your phone and jotting down a few thoughts in a notebook sound like thoughtful ways to ease into change without overwhelming yourself. You’re making room for progress, while still being kind to yourself. How do you feel about giving these ideas a try?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
